ACCIDENT HISTORY - LAST FIVE YEARS

This is a new process with no accidents.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

OSI Group is included in the written community emergency response plan.  The facility has its own emergency action plan.  The emergency action plan includes procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release.  The emergency action plan also includes information on emergency health care.

OSI Group does not respond to emergencies.  OSI Group coordinates its Emergency Action Plan with the City of Riverside Fire Department. 
 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

OSI Group in Riverside has recently performed a hazard analysis per their Process Safety Management and Risk Management programs.  Areas for improvement during the hazard analysis were identified and corrective actions recommended.  All recommendations are promptly addressed.

STEPS  

EPA's Risk Management Prevention Program 3, 40 CFR Part 68(D) and OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard 29 CFR 1910.119 outline the facilities accidental release prevention program.  Included are 13 Chemical Specific Prevention steps implemented by OSI Group and are summarized below.

Employee Participation - Employees are given shared responsibility with management in the continued evolution of the program.
Process Safety Information - Chemical, equipment, and system information has been compiled to ensure the safe design and operation.
Process Hazard Analysis - Hazardous Operability Study (HAZOP) completed to identify potential hazards and minimize their impact.
Operating Procedures - Standard Operating Procedures developed to ensure the safe operation of the process.
Training - Training program established and operators trained to ensure the safe operation of the process.
Contractors - Contractor program established to ensure only qualified and trained contractor work on or near the process.
Pre-Startup Safety Review - Procedures and checklist developed to ensure all safety requirements completed before startup of new or modified process.
Mechanical Integrity - Program developed to ensure equipment and systems installed per design specifications and maintained per manufacturer recommendations and good engineering practices.
Hot Work Permit - Permit program established to prevent the potential of fire/explosion resulting from hot work near hazardous chemicals.
Management of Change - Procedures established to manage process changes to ensure the integrity of the PSM program is maintained.
Incident Investigations - Procedures established to investigate releases that resulted in or could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a hazardous chemical to prevent reoccurrence.
Compliance Audits - Procedures established to periodically review program implementation and to correct as necessary.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

OSI Group in Riverside, CA has developed a Risk Management Program in compliance with the Environmental Protection Agencies final Rule 40 CFR Part 68 and Article 3 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia with a total inventory charge over the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.  Since the facility is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's PSM Standard 29 CFR 1910.119, Program 3 is required.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICY

The top priority of OSI Group is to provide a healthy and safe work environment for its employees and the surrounding community.  In this effort OSI Group has developed strict policies and procedures to reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous chemical release.  The Process Safety Management (PSM) program acts as a gatekeeper of these policies and procedures.

The requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) PSM Standard 29 CFR 1910.119 mirrors that of Risk Management's Prevention Program 3 and therefore been integrated.  Of the 14 PSM elements 13 focus on accidental release prevention and one on emergency planning and response.  It is the commitment of management and employees to follow the established procedures and seek new ways for improvement. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY

In the event of an emergency and depending on the type and magnitude of the emergency, OSI Group will evacuate or shelter in place its employees and call the City of Riverside Fire Department to respond to the emergency.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

OSI Group is a food manufacturer located in Riverside, California.  The process includes refrigerated spaces that utilize anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.  Anhydrous ammonia is a regulated substance under the Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions, 40 CFR 68.
